title: كَأَيِّنْ وَكَذَا
description: Learn about كَأَيِّنْ (how many/many a) and كَذَا (such and such a number) - two classical Arabic quantity expressions found in the Quran and classical texts.

notes.title: Introduction to كَأَيِّنْ
content: كَأَيِّنْ (also written كَائِن) is a classical Arabic word meaning 'how many' or 'many a.' It's similar in meaning to كَمْ الخَبَرِيَّة (exclamatory كم).
It appears frequently in the Quran and classical poetry. Unlike كَمْ, the noun after كَأَيِّنْ is مَجْرُور بِمِنْ (genitive with مِن).

examples.english: And how many a prophet fought... (Quran 3:146)
And how many a sign... (Quran 12:105)
And how many a town We destroyed... (Quran 22:45)

examples.arabic: كَأَيِّنْ مِنْ دَابَّةٍ لَا تَحْمِلُ رِزْقَهَا
examples.english: How many a creature carries not its provision (Quran 29:60)

notes.title: Grammar of كَأَيِّنْ
content: كَأَيِّنْ is a كِنَايَة عَنِ الْعَدَد (expression for number) in the nominative position (مَحَلّ رَفْع أو نَصْب). It's مَبْنِيّ on sukoon.
The تَمْيِيز (specification) after كَأَيِّنْ is مَجْرُور بِمِنْ, not مَنْصُوب like after كَمْ. This is the key grammatical difference.

examples.english: How many a man I saw (رجلٍ = مجرور)
How many men I saw (رجلًا = منصوب)

examples.arabic: كَأَيِّنْ: في محل رفع مبتدأ أو نصب مفعول
examples.english: Position: mubtada' or maf'ool
And how many an angel... (Quran 53:26)

notes.title: Introduction to كَذَا
content: كَذَا is a كِنَايَة عَنْ الْعَدَد meaning 'such and such a number' or 'so many.' It's used when the speaker knows the number but doesn't want to specify it.
It can be repeated for emphasis: كَذَا وَكَذَا (such and such). The noun after كَذَا is تَمْيِيز مَنْصُوب.

examples.english: I have such and such dirhams
Such and such men came
I bought it for so many dinars
I stayed for so many days

notes.title: Grammar of كَذَا
content: كَذَا is composed of كَ (like) + ذَا (this), but as a unit it functions as a number substitute. It is مَبْنِيّ in the position of the number it replaces.
The تَمْيِيز after كَذَا takes the same case as it would after the actual number: usually مَنْصُوب if the number is large (11+), or مَجْرُور if small.

examples.english: Takes position of number it replaces
I have X books (منصوب)
I bought X and Y garments
I read X pages

notes.title: Comparison: كَأَيِّنْ، كَمْ، كَذَا
content: كَمْ (exclamatory): تَمْيِيز مَنْصُوب or مَجْرُور بِمِنْ. كَأَيِّنْ: تَمْيِيز مَجْرُور بِمِنْ only. كَذَا: تَمْيِيز usually مَنْصُوب.
All three express quantity, but: كَمْ and كَأَيِّنْ = 'how many/many a' (large unspecified number). كَذَا = 'such and such' (known but unstated number).

examples.english: How many books (both valid)
How many a book (only مجرور)
X books (usually منصوب)
كم/كأيّن = abundance, كذا = vagueness

notes.title: Usage in Context
content: كَأَيِّنْ is primarily found in classical and Quranic Arabic, while كَذَا is used in both classical and modern contexts for avoiding specific numbers.
Both are important for understanding classical texts and Quranic tafsir. Modern Arabic often prefers كَمْ for exclamatory expressions.

examples.english: How many a sign in the heavens... (Quran 12:105)
So-and-so told me such and such
Its price is such and such
Say: How long did you remain? (question)

exercises.prompt: التَّمْيِيزُ بَعْدَ كَأَيِّنْ يَكُونُ مَجْرُورًا بِـ_____
exercises.promptEn: The تمييز after كأيّن is genitive with _____

exercises.prompt: كَذَا تَعْنِي: _____ وَكَذَا (عدد معلوم غير مذكور)
exercises.promptEn: كَذَا means: such and _____ (known but unstated number)

exercises.prompt: كَأَيِّنْ وَكَمْ وَكَذَا كُلُّهَا _____ عَنِ الْعَدَدِ
exercises.promptEn: كأيّن، كم، and كذا are all _____ for number
